g.text: , Zhiyuan Gao, Chong Geng, Shuangshuang Shi, Le Wang, Sijing Su and Wengang Bi
Perovskite quantum dots (QDs) have been widely used in white light-emitting diodes (WLEDs), due to their high
quantum yield (QY), tunable bandgap, and simple preparation. However, the red-emitting perovskite QDs are
usually containing iodine (I), which is not stable under continuous light irradiation. Herein, perovskite-based WLED is
fabricated by lead-free bismuth (Bi)-doped inorganic perovskites Cs
which emits white light with color coordinates of (0.334, 0.297). The Bi-doped Cs
both show excellent stability when kept in the ambient air. As benefits from this desired characteristic, the as-
prepared WLED shows excellent stability along with operating time. These results can promote the application of
inorganic perovskite QDs in the field of WLEDs.
Among solid-state lighting technology, white light-emitting
diodes (WLEDs) are excellent candidates to replace incan-
descent lamps for their merits of high-energy conservation,
long lifetime, high luminous efficiency, and polarized emis-
]. In general, WLEDs were recognized as one kind of
the economical and efficient solid-state lighting sources [
]. QD-LED technology is gradually developed over the past
few years, because of high stability and high quantum yield
attracted much attention, and they have been applied in
achieved because of their excellent absorption (Abs) coeffi-
cients, long carrier diffusion lengths, and high carrier mobil-
good optoelectronic performance including high responsivity
ing their great potential application in photodetection fields
]. Additionally, perovskites have been introduced into
photonic devices. The remarkable features of perovskite,
such as rich phase compositions and low-temperature solu-
tion process ability, made perovskite can be applied in tran-
and lasing can be realized by CsPbX
perovskite QDs are the most promising material among
QDs for LED application, due to high QY (up to > 90%), in-
ure, and highly tunable bandgaps (from 1.46 to 2.50 ev) [
]. However, the anion-exchange reaction between perov-
skites and instability of iodine (I)-containing perovskite
largely restricted the development of perovskite QDs toward
WLED application. Sun et al. proposed to use silica encapsu-
lation to enhance stability and avoid anion exchange [
The air stability of perovskite QDs was enhanced greatly, but
the WLED stability is not good enough because of the sig-
nificant dropping of red light. Then, Shen et al. used the an-
thracene shell to protect red-emitting perovskite QDs, which
enhanced the LED stability against current [
and coworkers also presented the same method to enhance
]. Due to the sharp emission lines of
perovskite QDs, they usually are used in backlight display ap-
WLEDs are not proper for solid-state lighting, because their
